FacilityStr1: US Hwy 181 N to FM 798 turn left
FacilityStr2: to CR 129 turn left go .4 miles

_prev_prog_2.FR_Comments: ASME used as the standard for storage tank construction and overfill protection
_prev_prog_2.MD_OtherType: All personnel working at or visiting the facility must wear Personal H2S Gas Alarm Monitors
_prev_prog_2.Description: This installation meets all requirements of NFPA 58 (Liquefied Petroleum Gas Code), and ASME Code requirements.  Safety relief valves, bypass flow valves, check valves, gas detection around pressurized bullet tanks and truck loading area and remote access emergency shutdown devices are in place at the facility.  The facility is manned continuously and monitored via SCADA on a 24 hours/day, 7days/week, 365 days/year basis by SCADA operators located at the Marathon Kenedy Office.  Employees have received hands-on fire extinguisher training along with function specific training as required by OSHA.  New employees receive classroom instruction as well as one-on-one training with experienced employees prior to being allowed to operate any equipment.  The facility is equipped with a flare system that prevents atmospheric release of product.  Marathon has a Safe Work Permitting program and Lockout/Tagout procedures which are strictly enforced.  Marathon's Safe Work Permitting program covers various tasks (e.g., hot work, confined space entry, vehicle access to restricted areas, high H2S situations, and any other hazardous work that requires additional planning and/or monitoring).  Marathon has an established event management process that requires reporting of events regardless of severity.  The process concludes with implementation of corrective and preventative measures.  This facility conducts periodic Process Hazard Analysis studies.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Natural gas and associated liquids enter the facility via pipeline from several Central Production Facilities.  The natural gas and associated liquids enter the facility through a pig trap and a multi-finger slug catcher.  Gas from the slug catcher is compressed by one of four single staged flow-through compressors, dehydrated by one of two glycol dehydration units then sent to multiple sales points via two sales scrubbers.  The liquids from the slug catcher are routed to the liquids side of the process where any water is separated from the liquids.  The liquids flow through a caustic wash system to remove H2S, and a carbon filtration unit to treat the color (if needed) for pipeline quality purposes. The resulting LNG is then stored in pressurized bullet tanks prior to exiting the facility via pipeline (the normal operation mode after June 2013), or by truck (used during periods of pipeline shutdowns) to a third party gas plant for further processing.  LNG is considered hazardous by the EPA.  Because LNG is pressurized flammable gas, it is necessary to follow safety precautions during handling to prevent fire/explosion risks and reduce health threats to our workers and neighbors.  Marathon has implemented various health and safety programs and processes and will strictly adhere to all Federal, State, and Local rules and regulations.   



Safety depends on:        

(a) The manner in which we handle this product        

(b) The safety devices inherent in the design of the facility        

(c) Operating and maintenance procedures, and         

(d) Employee training    



Marathon Eagle Ford Asset Team's emergency response program details employee responsibilities, actions and includes procedures for notification of the local fire authority and the LEPC to notify potentially affected neighbors. 

                

The primary purpose of this facility is to:                

(a) Receive and store Liquified Petroleum Gas from surrounding production wells;                

(b) Remove excess water and contaminants                

(c) Transf

er gas product to gas processors sales lines    



This facility was designed and constructed in accordance with NFPA 58 and ASME codes and applicable API standards. A Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA) system has been installed and continually monitors each unit in the process as well by personnel stationed at the facility.  All employees are thouroughly trained on the characteristics and safe handling procedures for liquified natural gas. Access is restricted to authorized facility employees, authorized management personnel and authorized contractors. Marathon Oil has implemented a variety of safe work practices and procedures to minimize risk to the employees and surrounding neighbors.
